title: 111_hr6460
content: The Act titled "Transparency and Security in Mortgage Registration Act of 2010" prohibits guaranteeing MERS mortgages. After the enactment of the Transparency and Security in Mortgage Registration Act of 2010, Fannie Mae is prohibited from dealing with MERS mortgages. MERS will no longer be named as the mortgagee on any mortgage owned, guaranteed, or securitized by the corporation after a specified period. The Transparency and Security in Mortgage Registration Act of 2010 prohibits Fannie Mae from dealing with MERS mortgages. The mortgagee of record must be assigned to the servicer, holder, or creditor as defined by the corporation. The corporation will not reimburse any expenses for such assignments. The act specifies a 6-month period for compliance, with exceptions for cases where compliance poses a severe threat to the financial viability of the entity. The Transparency and Security in Mortgage Registration Act of 2010 prohibits Fannie Mae from dealing with MERS mortgages. The act specifies a 6-month compliance period, with exceptions for cases threatening financial viability. The corporation must report compliance to various entities within 6 months, with possible extensions granted. The Transparency and Security in Mortgage Registration Act of 2010 defines MERS and MERS mortgages. It also amends the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation Act to include provisions related to MERS. After the enactment of the Transparency and Security in Mortgage Registration Act of 2010, the Corporation is prohibited from dealing with MERS mortgages. MERS cannot be the named mortgagee on any mortgage owned, guaranteed, or securitized by the Corporation after a certain period. All mortgages with MERS as the named mortgagee must be assigned to the servicer, holder, or creditor defined by the Corporation. The Corporation will not reimburse for any expenses related to this assignment. The period for assigning mortgages from MERS to designated entities is 6 months after the Transparency and Security in Mortgage Registration Act of 2010. However, for mortgages that pose a severe threat to the financial viability of the entity, the assignment period can be extended up to 12 months as determined by the Corporation. The Corporation must report its compliance with assigning mortgages from MERS to designated entities to various entities within 6 months, with possible extensions up to 12 months. Definitions for MERS and MERS mortgages are provided. The Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency must issue regulations within 90 days of the enactment of the Act to implement amendments related to MERS mortgages. Coordination with the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development is required for issuing these regulations. After the Transparency and Security in Mortgage Registration Act of 2010, Ginnie Mae is prohibited from guaranteeing or acquiring any trust certificate or security containing MERS mortgages. MERS is also restricted from being named as a mortgagee on any record after a specified period. Coordination with the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development is necessary for uniform regulations. MERS is prohibited from being named as a mortgagee on any mortgage owned by the Association or contained in a trust or pool backed by the Association. The Association must assign all mortgages with MERS as the named mortgagee to the servicer, holder, or creditor defined by Association guidelines. The Association will not reimburse for any expenses incurred in the assignment or recording process. The Transparency and Security in Mortgage Registration Act of 2010 sets a 6-month period for compliance with mortgage assignment rules, with exceptions for mortgages owned by the Association. Compliance causing financial harm allows for an extended period determined by the Secretary. The Transparency and Security in Mortgage Registration Act of 2010 sets a 6-month compliance period for mortgage assignment rules, with exceptions for Association-owned mortgages. The Association must submit a compliance report to various entities after the 6-month period, with definitions including MERS as Mortgage Electronic Registration Systems, Inc. The Transparency and Security in Mortgage Registration Act of 2010 requires compliance with mortgage assignment rules within 6 months, with exceptions for Association-owned mortgages. The Act defines MERS as Mortgage Electronic Registration Systems, Inc. Registration Systems, Inc., or any successor entity, is involved in the mortgage process. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must issue necessary regulations within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary must consult with the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency to ensure uniform regulations for mortgage assignment rules. HUD will conduct a study. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, with the Comptroller General, will conduct a study on the impacts of electronic records in local land title systems, progress in developing uniform standards, federal oversight in land title transfer, and opportunities for leveraging electronic systems. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, along with the Comptroller General, will study the feasibility of creating an electronic land title recordation system at the federal level, without interfering with state real property laws. This study will include maintaining all previous records of land property transfers. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, in consultation with the Comptroller General, will submit a report to Congress within 12 months of the enactment of this Act on the results of the study regarding the feasibility of an electronic land title recordation system at the federal level.
